as for the reading-writing dichotomy, I’m sure many of us go through that inversion from reading more to writing more, I certainly did. But maybe it’s more like a double-helix tangle that undulates between two poles.

One huge thing that changed then was that, prior to college, my “mood” was pretty…

paragraphs.text: Yeah, I think it has to do with love of language — both writer and reader — as well. Not necessary lyrical but powerful, conjuring image and sound, touch and taste and smell so effortlessly the reader isn’t aware of the words at all, but only the senses.

paragraphs.text: Well, I’ve always experienced reading in that way — and my mother did too. It didn’t disappear, but it now fluctuates, fighting with the critical in-brain editor that nags a lot. I hope you can return to reading with complete immersion, but I can tell you, it takes extremely good writing :)

paragraphs.text: Thank you for writing this article. I enjoyed it immensely, and I also experience 3D immersive reading, and always have. Like you, I assumed everybody read that way. Now that I’m an adult, it doesn’t happen every time I read, but as some of the others here have suggested, it happens when certain factors are present in the writing. I would love to…

content.subtitle: The second was about about a death ray that boiled the humans’ blood. I felt it in my own body.

paragraphs.name: 49f0
paragraphs.text: Never experienced 3-D immersive reading, but… I have experienced 3-D immersive writing! I wrote my first two stories when I was maybe 10 or 12 or 11. The first was about how you would get in your car, choose a destination on the screen, any destination at all, push the button and the car would take you there. I was in that car!

d814f23352c6.title: Never experienced 3-D immersive reading, but… I have experienced 3-D immersive writing!

virtuals.subtitle: The second was about about a death ray that boiled the humans’ blood. I felt it in my own body.

paragraphs.name: 3e0d
paragraphs.text: Did you find that mood affects the degree? I can put down a lot of books searching for the one that matches a kind of restless quest passion. When I find it, bingo, it’s there and I’m gone.

paragraphs.name: 2a24
paragraphs.text: There’s a clue here, Jeffrey, one that I almost don’t want to look at (though I will). Having written this piece, it occurred to me for the first time that when I first became aware that my ability to disappear into reading had changed coincided with entering a university writing program. Could it be that learning how to write somehow dulled my ability to read? That’s a weird thought, but it’s one I need to consider. My great weakness as a writer (to balance bragging about my superpower — haha) is that, when writing, I am about as far from “3-D immersive writing” as it is possible to get. I write slowly, ploddingly, building essays and stories and poems one word or sentence at a time, like a kid stacking Legos. The end product is usually pretty OK. But it takes forever. This little 1,000 word essay, for example, took about 8 hours to compose to my satisfaction. I’ll bet there is some weird connection between how I learned to write and the change in how I read. Interesting… Thanks for the food for thought, Jeffrey!

paragraphs.name: 2a24
paragraphs.text: There’s a clue here, Jeffrey, one that I almost don’t want to look at (though I will). Having written this piece, it occurred to me for the first time that when I first became aware that my ability to disappear into reading had changed coincided with entering a university writing program. Could it be that learning how to write somehow dulled my ability to read? That’s a weird thought, but it’s one I need to consider. My great weakness as a writer (to balance bragging about my superpower — haha) is that, when writing, I am about as far from “3-D immersive writing” as it is possible to get. I write slowly, ploddingly, building essays and stories and poems one word or sentence at a time, like a kid stacking Legos. The end product is usually pretty OK. But it takes forever. This little 1,000 word essay, for example, took about 8 hours to compose to my satisfaction. I’ll bet there is some weird connection between how I learned to write and the change in how I read. Interesting… Thanks for the food for thought, Jeffrey!
